awd_titl_txt: Physical Manifestations of Chaos and Regularity Around Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
Everything in the Universe is in motion: planets orbit stars, stars orbit within galaxies, and galaxies orbit each other.  We have expectations for how these orbits should behave.  Planets follow elliptical orbits around stars.  They repeat the same path millions or even billions of times over the years with each revolution taking the same amount of time, known as the 'period'.  The stars themselves follow orbits that form 'rosette' patterns as they move through a galaxy.  These orbits can take hundreds of millions of years to go even once around. Rosette orbits can be described with two periods: the 'azimuthal period' encapsulates how long it takes for the star to go around the galaxy; the 'radial period' describes how long it take for the star to get between the points along its orbit that are closest to and farthest from the galaxy's center and back again. 

The nature of stellar orbits is set by the distribution of matter that influences them.  Planets move around matter that is concentrated in the central stars.  Stars in the galaxy are moving within the combined distribution of stars, gas, and dark matter.  Both elliptical and rosette orbits are known as 'regular' orbits since their paths are predictable and repeating.  However, it is also expected that some orbits in the Universe are 'chaotic.'  These orbits do not have patterns that repeat with well-defined periods and hence are not predictable.  And---just as the nature of elliptical and rosette orbits is set by the matter distribution---so is the importance of chaos.  Orbits are more likely to be chaotic if the visible and dark matter distributions are complex.

The investigator will also continue her work with underrepresented groups in the sciences.  She seeks to facilitate institutional structures to gain benefits from a diverse workforce; reduce the challenges of making decisions among diverse groups; provide support for minorities in leadership roles in academia; and ease the transition as academic institutions evolve.

While the nature of planetary orbits around stars can be observed within human lifetimes, the vast sizes of galaxies means that orbits of stars take millions of years.  The proposed work will explore a new mathematical approach to deducing the nature of stellar orbits around galaxies, whether they are regular or chaotic.  Over the last 20 years, streams of stars on similar orbits have been observed around our Galaxy.  In prior work, the proposers have shown that the morphologies of these streams are sensitive to the presence (or absence) of chaos.  Only on very regular orbits can these streams remain coherent.  And the presence of chaos can tell us about how the elusive dark matter around galaxies is distributed.

Theoretical studies of the nature of orbits---regular or chaotic---in dynamical systems (galaxies being just one example) are essential to building a deep understanding of the global structures that the orbits support.  In recent work the investigator has discovered that signatures of the nature of orbits can be observed in structures around our own Galaxy, formed from the disruption of satellite systems.  They found one stellar stream associated with globular cluster Palomar 5 that is long and thin with a simple structure.   Another stream of stars in the constellation Ophiucus is extraordinarily truncated.  The investigator will (i) explore the physical manifestations of regularity and chaos in stellar debris more generally and (ii) develop methods for making maps of the nature of orbits around galaxies using these signatures.  The project combines tools and techniques from the classical study of non-linear dynamics with numerical experiments that follow the evolution of ensembles of orbits starting from initial conditions closely clustered in phase-space.  They will extend their study to two new regimes: the evolution of chaotic orbits over short timescales (tens of orbits) and the observable signatures of this evolution in the full phase-space structure of ensembles of orbits.  They will also explore how regular and chaotic orbits can support stellar structures beyond the traditional study of self-consistent galactic components, including unbound stellar associations.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The Milky Way is our home galaxy. Its visible components contains hundreds of billions of stars as well as gas and dust. The way the stars, gas and dust are moving suggest that they are embedded within a much more extended and much more massive halo of dark matter. All of these constituents are constantly interacting through the force of gravity: it is their combined mass distribution governs the orbits of all the stars within the galaxy. Greater understanding of the nature of the orbits of the stars will therefore give us some clues to the structure of our Galaxy, seen and unseen components.

The major challenge to understadning the nature of Galactic orbits is that we cannot observe them overy time - we can only measure a star's present position and motion. This grant supported research to examine specific subsets of stars that orbit the Milky Way in coherent streams. These streams are particularly useful as probes of our Galaxy's combined mass distribution since they represent sets of stars that have very similar orbital properties. Even though we can't measure the individual orbital properties, we can assess the degree to which nearby orbits are similar or diverge from the morphology and existence of these streams.

Prior work had demonstrated that the degree of coherence of the streams reflected the natures of the orbits of the stars - in particular whether they were regular (steadily repeating predictable patterns), or chaotic and unpredictable. During the course of this grant we found more specifically that a stream's deviations form strict coherence couold be attributed to stars on closely related orbits having very different orbital properties. We demonstrated that this occurred in regions known as separatrices in orbit space. Exactly where these separatrices exist depends on the mass distribution. Hence our work suggests that the morphology of observed streams in some regions of the Galaxy - or the lack of streams in other regions - could be used to map its orbital structure and subsequently its mass distribution.

Our work is very timely for the field of Astronomy. In the last 5 years, the number of stream known to exist round the Milky Way has grown dramatically, from roughly 10 to nearly 100. Moreover, our investigation could have broader implications beyond Astronomy to other fields where the dynamics of closely related groups of objects are followed. 

Broader Impacts

Science is explored by scientists - people who are collaboraating together to push the bounderies of human knowledge. The extent to which we are able to fulfill our collective potential to adfvance science therefore depends on very human interactions.

During the course of the grant the PI has combined her experiences over decades as an astronomer and more recently as an academic leader with an exploration of literature and concepts form the social sciences. She wrote a paper to share what she learned with her colleagues - entitled "Power, Privilege and Leadership in Acadmia" and publised it in the journal Nature Astronomy. She has so far given ? talks on this work.

The PI has also applied her learning to help construct frameworks that support the people building knowlege in science and academia to make the most of the full diversity of backgrounds and perspectives they represent. These indlude the development of two programs.
1) A cross-departmental approach at Columbia to supporting transformational initiatives called Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and  Accessibilty Strategies. She is working on a new paper with co-developers of the program on the outcomes.
2) An innovative postdoctoral program, the LSSTC Catalyst Fellows Program, which recruits both scientists and social scientists to help each other with professional development.
